For systematic conservation planning and setting conservation priorities it is imperative to know about species distributions and their relationship with biotic and abiotic factors
68– 70 . However, despite their ecological roles in the ecosystem, particularity in the Sahara and the Arabian Desert, mammal species are widely neglected from conservation plans, and not even fully recognised by the local governments
2, 19, 27 . The ecological role that many mammal species play makes them ideal umbrella or keystone species. Prioritising the conservation efforts towards these species would provide collateral protection to co-occurring species
22 . For instance, the recruitment of Acacia species, a keystone species in the Sahara and the Arabian Desert, increased with the presence of herbivore species (e.g. Dorcas gazelle Gazella dorcas)
71 . Unlike other herbivorous species, Dorcas gazelles are known to be browsers and not grazers, which, in turn, allows the vegetation cover for the desert ecosystem to survive and persist, in addition they also act as plant seeds dispersers
72– 74 . At the same time, the gazelles are the main prey for several predators (e.g. Cheetah Acinonyx jubatus and Wolf Canis lupus) that have suffered from decline in prey availability
75 .
